text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to have Thai kitchen today I'm 
going to show you how to make tamarind paste for

cooking from a block of pulp like this and I'll 
also show you how to process it so that you can

make it in bulk and keep it in the fridge for 
months and months so you only have to make this

like once every six months or so so if you've been 
following the show earlier you would have noticed

that I used to use Tamarind that comes in a top like 
this which is convenient and everything and it's

fine but I'm moving away from that because I'm 
realizing now the flavor and the acidity is a lot

better when you do make it from pulp like this and 
that's why I wanted to make this video to update

the information for you I also want to point out 
that I do have a video all about the basics of

tamarind tamarind 101 everything you need to know 
so you've got more questions about tamarind check

out that video I will link it in the description 
below alright let's get started so for today I'm

only gonna make just have a block you can do the 
whole thing if you want but personally for me

half a block is fine and this stuff last in the 
fridge like forever so you don't have to worry

about it going bad super simple you want to start 
by breaking this into sort of small chunks like

this so it takes less time to dissolve in the 
water if you add the whole chunk in just take

forever and you could just use a knife to cut it 
into cubes but I think it's actually easier like

this and you can open up more surface area make 
it soak even faster okay so now that goes into a

large bowl now to this I'm just gonna add hot 
water and this water can be as hot rap can be

as hot as you want it can be off the boil but it 
doesn't have to be pros and cons the hotter it is

the longer you have to wait before you can start 
mashing it with your hands but hot water will

dissolve the tamarind more thoroughly so don't 
go with like lukewarm tap water things like that

that'll that'll make it harder for you to mash 
it afterwards so at this point and what I do

is I just let it sit and just go do something else 
forget about it it'll take about 30 minutes before

it's cool enough for me to stick my hands in there 
so here's our Terran after it's been sitting it's

kind of lukewarm right now yes I know it does 
not look appealing but this will pass trust me

so before I do anything this is a lot more full 
than I had anticipated so I'm just gonna move it

into a bigger bowl so I can just like scrunch at 
it without worrying about spilling all right so

now you're just gonna go in and massage the flesh 
off of the fibers that is in here so there are

no seeds in the pulp and the package will say 
seedless but there are a lot of fiber that is

that is covering the seeds so you have to strain 
that out and I'm only wearing gloves just you know

for hygienic reasons but if you wash your hands 
very well and you don't worry about Tamron and

your nails then you can do it bare hands so yeah 
you just want to feel with your fingers that each

seed fiber no longer has soft pulp on it and 
really take your time because you don't want

to waste anything here and my tip is for this 
part don't add too much water because if it's

too runny it's harder to find the stuff like it's 
just kind of swimming around so generally I do a

half pound block for two cups of water jet works 
out pretty well so that looks good and now I'm

gonna strain this into a pot because we're gonna 
cook it I got a sieve here don't go with a super

fine mesh sieve because this is quite thick and 
something superfine will make it harder so this

sieve is good it's quite coarse so all that goes 
in mmm and you're just gonna try to stir it and

press it all into the pot it's a little thick so 
you really need to get in with your hands and help

push it along just push all the fibers against 
the sieve and then because I'm stingy I'm going

to rinse whatever is left here with a little 
more water cuz I want everything gosh darn it
okay there we go

really squeeze that through make sure you get 
everything off the bottom and that is it so

now this is good to use for cooking right 
away but if you want to keep it for a long

time you want to cook this first kill off all 
the bacteria and everything in it will last a

lot longer so I'm just gonna bring this to a 
boil and because it's so thick I would keep

stirring to prevent it from jumping and landing 
on your arm that would not be pleasant so now

that it is boiling ready for the cans okay so 
I like to use mason jars because if you add a

really hot thing to a mason jar it creates a 
vacuum seal so then it'll last longer but you

can use any container that you like something 
that seals well I am generally pretty good at

pouring but you might want to use a funnel this 
is the perfect thickness right here if you're

trying to sort of replicate the store-bought 
version this is a great ratio Oh perfect so

this makes exactly two cups and a little bit 
I have like a tablespoon left in here which I

will just turn into a drink after close that 
now as you can see I'm not going through the

proper canning method like I'm not boiling these 
like you would a jar of jam so I'm still going

to keep this in the fridge but if you want to 
go ahead and can them so that you can keep at

room temperature for years and years you can do 
that too and that is it oh you know what now that

we're here let me taste it mmm oh nice and sour 
I'm flavorful also it's a good idea to taste it

because different brands different batches have 
slightly different acidity so you might want to

take that into consideration when you make a red 
it's good to know where you're starting at right

so this batch is very sour more sour than my last 
batch so I know that when I use it for cooking I

gotta use a little bit less so I hope that was 
helpful if you got more questions about tamarind

don't forget to check out my Tamron 101 video I'll 
link to it below we cover a lot of things in that

video when you make this I want to see a photo 
of it maybe you can use it as a Christmas gift

for a Thai food loving friend if you haven't 
subscribed to the show make sure you do so

you don't miss an episode like this and click 
the bell icon as well so you get a notification

when I post a new video thank you as always for 
watching and I will see you next time for you
